description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Blue Jay.
title: All About the Blue Jay

slides.title: Introduction to the Blue Jay
slides.content: The Blue Jay (Cyanocitta cristata) is a striking bird native to eastern North America. Its name is derived from its loud call and its brilliant blue plumage. They are known for their intelligence and complex social systems.

slides.title: Diet and Feeding Habits
content: Blue Jays have a diverse diet that includes nuts, seeds, fruits, and insects. They are particularly fond of acorns.
They are known for their habit of storing food in hidden caches for later consumption, which helps to disperse trees like oaks.

slides.title: Calls and Communication
content: Blue Jays are highly vocal and have a wide range of calls, including a loud 'jay-jay' sound.
They are also excellent mimics and can imitate the calls of other birds, especially hawks, which they use to warn of predators or to intimidate other animals.

slides.title: Intelligence and Behavior
content: Blue Jays are considered one of the most intelligent birds. They can solve puzzles and are capable of using tools.
They form strong social bonds and live in small family groups, often staying together through the winter.

slides.title: Habitat and Conservation
content: Blue Jays inhabit a wide range of habitats, from dense forests to suburban yards and parks.
Their population is considered stable, but they are vulnerable to habitat loss and deforestation. Protecting their natural habitats is crucial for their survival.
